result.execSummary:
The defendant Salvador J. Casarez was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Payable as follows:  $50.00 due on or before May 1, 2016 and on the same day thereafter each month, until paid in full.    Failure to pay any part of the court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.  $15.00 payment plan fee added.
Sentence to start on or before April 18, 2016 at 6:00 P.M.  If defendant consumes alcohol and is arrested for same, sentence to start immediately.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Defendant's request for a payment plan.
Defendant called.  4 warrants were issued for failure to pay.  $312.13 is 25% of total owed $1248.50 on 4 cases.  Explained that he has to pay 25% and then set up payment plan. smw

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Wilson.  Plead no contest to charge.   Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count he is pleading to.  Defendant understood.  Defendant plead guilty.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defendant understood.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Count 1 as charged.  State recommending jail or fine.  Defense requests 10 day jail sentence with EMP.  Start 4/18.  Credit for 3 days served.   Court ordered:  10 days jail.  Credit for 3 days served.  CC.  Start 4/18 at 6 pm.  Stay lifted if consume alcohol and arrested for same.  Set up payment plan.  $50/mo starting 5/1/16.
Plea/sentencing hearing at 04-04-2016 10:00 am

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.
Reading of the complaint waived.  Defendant stood mute.  NGP entered by court.  PTC 2/3 and STC 2/22.
DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Wilson.  Warrant quashed.  Bond set.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.
